page.title: 16The Fardel stone,Cornwood
page.content: The British Museum houses a granite standing-stone,known as the Fardel stone,which bears inscriptions both in Latin & Ogham(the written representa- tion of the sign language of the Druids,priests to the Celts) The stone is probably mid 5th century.It was discovered in the 186O's forming part of a culvert over a stream flowing to Fardel Manor.The stone is linked to the manor by the locally known couplet "Between this stone and Fardel Hall, Lies more money than the Devil can haul"(a poss. ref.to treasure buried during the Civil War) Tradition has it that the field,containing this gold, must never be ploughed,or untold evil will be released and by the following morning the furrows will have been turned back into the earth.Mr.Dennis (Fardel farm)says there is no truth in the curse,but of the gold..'who knows'
